command.command_structure_notes: Division surrendered at Axis capitulation in Tunisia, 13 May 1943. Quarter covers April-May combat operations and June POW status.

total_personnel.notes: Significantly under-strength due to combat losses and supply shortages during Tunisia campaign. Final strength at surrender approximately 6,000-7,000 men.

officers.notes: Officer casualties were heavy during defensive fighting in Tunisia

enlisted.notes: Enlisted strength depleted by combat attrition and lack of replacements

top_3_infantry_weapons.notes: Standard German infantry rifle, shortages due to supply disruption
Medium machine gun, critical shortages in ammunition
For NCOs and close-quarters combat troops

ground_vehicles_total.notes: Vehicle strength critically low due to fuel shortages, combat losses, and lack of spare parts. Most transport was horse-drawn or requisitioned civilian vehicles by 1943-Q2.

tanks.notes: Light division - no organic tank battalion. Any armor support came from attached units from panzer divisions.

artillery_total.notes: Artillery regiment severely depleted. Ammunition supply critical throughout Tunisia campaign.

aircraft_total.notes: No organic air assets. Luftwaffe support minimal by 1943-Q2 due to Allied air superiority.

supply_logistics.fuel_status: Critical - less than 25% of requirements. Fuel shortage severely limited mobility and tactical flexibility.
supply_logistics.ammunition_status: Severe shortage - artillery and mortar ammunition rationed to essential defensive fires only.
supply_logistics.water_supply: Adequate from local Tunisian sources, but distribution difficult due to transport shortages.
supply_logistics.operational_radius: 15-20 kilometers - severely limited by fuel shortage and vehicle breakdown rate exceeding 60%.
supply_logistics.supply_line_status: Collapsed - Allied naval and air interdiction cut off sea supply routes from Sicily. Ground supply lines under constant air attack.

weather_environment.terrain: Mountainous Tunisian terrain - steep hills, narrow valleys, limited road network. Defensive terrain favoring small unit actions.
weather_environment.temperature_range: April-May: 15-28°C (moderate spring temperatures). June POW period: 20-35°C (hot early summer).
weather_environment.seasonal_impacts: Spring rains created mud and limited mobility in April. Drying conditions in May improved trafficability but increased dust clouds revealing positions to Allied aircraft.
weather_environment.environmental_challenges: Rugged terrain limited vehicle mobility. Supply transport extremely difficult on mountain tracks. Allied air superiority prevented daylight movement.
weather_environment.operational_conditions: Defensive operations in mountainous terrain. Final battles fought with backs to sea, no retreat possible. Surrender imminent by end of quarter.

subordinate_units.notes: Three battalion infantry regiment. Motorization largely theoretical by 1943-Q2 due to vehicle losses.
Three battalion infantry regiment. Reduced strength from combat casualties.
Three battalion infantry regiment. Heavily engaged in Tunisia defensive operations.

equipment.notes: Heavy field howitzer, critical ammunition shortage

subordinate_units.notes: Four battalion artillery regiment reduced to two-battalion strength by losses and supply shortages.
Assigned 14 August 1942. Provided close infantry support.

equipment.notes: Heavy infantry support gun, ammunition scarce

subordinate_units.notes: Assigned 14 August 1942. Reduced effectiveness due to ammunition rationing.

equipment.notes: Dual-purpose anti-aircraft/anti-tank gun, critically important for ground defense
Light anti-aircraft gun, also effective against ground targets

subordinate_units.notes: Flak battalion essential for both air defense and anti-tank defense. Under constant engagement due to Allied air superiority.
Motorcycle and armored car reconnaissance. Severely limited by fuel shortages and vehicle losses.
Combat engineers for demolitions, minefield construction, and defensive fortifications. Critically important in Tunisia defensive positions.
Division medical services, under severe strain due to high casualty rates
Supply transport and distribution, critically hampered by vehicle and fuel shortages

combat_history.previous_quarter_summary: 1943-Q1: Fought in defensive operations during Axis retreat from El Alamein through Libya into Tunisia. Established defensive positions in Tunisian mountains.
combat_history.current_quarter_operations: April-May 1943: Defensive combat in Tunisia Campaign. Fought in mountainous terrain against overwhelming Allied numerical and material superiority. Division surrounded and captured at Axis surrender 13 May 1943. June 1943: Prisoners of war.

casualties_current_quarter.notes: Entire division captured at Tunisia surrender. Total casualties for quarter approximately 8,600 (killed, wounded, missing, plus 6,800 captured = entire division strength).

equipment_serviceability.notes: Vehicle serviceability critically low due to lack of spare parts, fuel, and maintenance facilities. Many vehicles abandoned or destroyed during final retreat.

unit_awards_decorations.notes: Authorized for service in North Africa

unique_features: Light division organization - three infantry regiments instead of standard two-regiment infantry division
Specialized for mobile operations in North African desert terrain
No organic tank battalion - relied on attached armor for tank support
Division formed specifically for African theater from elements of 164. Infantry Division
By 1943-Q2, division was trapped in Tunisia with no means of evacuation
Surrender on 13 May 1943 meant division ceased to exist as fighting force during this quarter

primary_sources: Nafziger Collection file 942GXMB - German 164th Light Afrika Division, 1942
The Rommel Papers (Liddell Hart edition) - references to 328th Infantry Regiment and 164th Light Division, July 1942
German Army Handbook 1939-45 - light division organization and doctrine

Precise casualty figures for Tunisia campaign

required_field_gaps: Detailed vehicle inventory by type for 1943-Q2
Complete artillery ammunition stocks at start of quarter
Exact date of final reorganizations before surrender

gap_documentation.personnel_strength: 1942 authorized strength used as baseline, with estimated 30-40% attrition applied based on general Afrika Korps losses during Tunisia campaign. Primary sources (Nafziger) provide 1942 organization but not 1943-Q2 specific strength returns.
gap_documentation.vehicle_inventory: Severe shortages documented in general sources (Rommel Papers) but specific 164th Division vehicle counts for 1943-Q2 not found in available sources. 35% operational rate estimated from general Afrika Korps conditions.
gap_documentation.artillery_ammunition: Critical shortages documented throughout Tunisia campaign in secondary sources, but specific ammunition stock levels for 164th Division not found in primary sources reviewed.
gap_documentation.organizational_changes: 1942 structure from Nafziger file assumed to remain largely intact through 1943-Q2, though combat losses certainly reduced battalion and company strengths. Specific reorganizations not documented in available sources.

validation.extraction_methodology: Primary source: Nafziger collection file 942GXMB provides 1942 base organization. Adjusted for 1943-Q2 conditions using Rommel Papers context about Tunisia campaign, German Army Handbook doctrine, and general Afrika Korps supply/strength situation documented in secondary sources. Commander and major battles verified against multiple sources.
validation.historical_accuracy_notes: High confidence in base organization (from Nafziger primary source). Medium confidence in 1943-Q2 specific strength figures (estimated from known attrition patterns). High confidence in operational conditions and surrender circumstances (well-documented historical event). Division designation, regiments, and support units verified across multiple sources.

notes: 164. leichte Division formed from 164. Infanterie-Division specifically for service in North Africa
Three-regiment structure (125th, 382nd, 433rd Panzergrenadier) was unusual for German divisions by 1943
Division fought in El Alamein defensive battles (July-November 1942) before retreating to Tunisia
By 1943-Q2, division was part of the trapped Axis forces in Tunisia with no evacuation possible
Surrender on 13 May 1943 ended the division's combat history - entire division became POWs
This quarter (1943-Q2) covers both active combat operations (April-May) and POW status (June)
Supply situation catastrophic by May 1943 - fuel, ammunition, food all critically short
Allied air superiority made daylight movement impossible, severely limiting tactical options
Division never reconstituted after Tunisia surrender - designation not reused
